0.00.text:
Translator: Walter Wekkesser
Reviewer: Denise RQ

6.75.text:
Hello. Alright, deep web.
What is the deep web?

10.07.text:
Actually, it is the hidden part
of the Internet;

12.91.text:
I could go into more detail,
no time, but let's just say

16.41.text:
- but actually is as dull as
dishwater, most of it -

21.76.text:
the hidden part of the Internet
is the kind of place

24.76.text:
where if you want to be anonymous,
you most certainly can,

28.39.text:
but, in many ways,
we are looking at a parallel universe,

32.07.text: we are looking at an alternative Internet,

34.61.text:
a place where people 
communicate secretly and securely

39.14.text: away from the prying eyes of governments.

43.71.text: At this level of the deep web,

45.18.text:
we are looking at a mirror image
of the regular Internet, the surface web.

51.06.text: You have got websites and bulletin boards,

53.26.text:
you've got clones of Twitter and Facebook,
and all the rest of the things

57.57.text:
that you would normally expect
from the Internet.

60.19.text: So, who is using this stuff?

62.12.text: Well, actually, all sorts of people:

65.06.text:
journalists and activists,
aid workers and dissidents,

70.46.text:
whistle-blowers and free-speech advocates,
criminals and spies,

74.00.text:
all sorts of people use deep web tools
to be anonymous on the Internet.

79.98.text:
I will show you 
some of the things that they do,

82.30.text:
but I would like
to propose that we all start

84.49.text:
to think about learning 
some of the secrets of the deep web,

87.47.text: the black arts, if you will,

89.34.text:
to try and solve some of the problems
of the Internet today.

92.90.text: And the way I see it,

94.41.text: the Internet is facing three main threats.

98.81.text:
Threat number one, 
you might call it 'the NSA phantom.'

102.35.text:
We have all seen and read
the Edward Snowden's revelations.

106.12.text:
We all know we've been monitored
all of the time.

109.66.text:
This, ultimately, is going to have
a terrible effect on the Internet,

112.90.text:
and it might get to the point where people
are frightened to speak openly,

117.43.text:
rather like North Korea
or the old East Germany,

119.98.text:
where the phones were tapped,
or people were followed in the street,

127.01.text: Here is a fun thing you can try at home:

130.68.text:
next time you send 
an e-mail to your mom, say,

141.52.text:
and let's see how long it takes them
to come and get you and your mom.

148.46.text:
You can find my e-mail address,
please get in touch

151.01.text: because I'd like to know what happens.

153.11.text:
Did the SWAT team come
and kick your door down?

156.11.text:
Did you find yourself
on an airline no-fly list?

159.22.text: Or did nothing happen? Or so you think.

161.61.text:
Because I actually think
by monitoring us, the public at large,

165.76.text:
they are missing the point,
they are barking up the wrong tree,

168.73.text: they are looking in the wrong place.

171.16.text:
Because no terrorist worth their salt
is going to give anything away

175.64.text: in an e-mail or on the phone.

179.31.text:
Osama Bin Laden
did not have a Facebook page

186.29.text: and he never twitted his friends.

190.34.text:
So, you have to ask,
why they are monitoring us all?

193.48.text:
I think they do it
simply because they can.

197.33.text:
Every government would want to know
what its people are saying and thinking.

203.81.text:
So, bear that in mind
next time there is a terrorist event,

207.33.text:
like the appalling murder
in Woolwich, South London, last year

213.45.text:
As quick as a flash, the government
used that as an opportunity to say:

217.17.text:
"We need to monitor the public at large."
"We need more monitoring."

222.22.text: But, correct me if I'm wrong,

223.92.text:
I don't think 
there was any evidence to suggest

226.28.text:
that the perpetrators
of this appalling crime

229.35.text:
actually discussed their intentions
on e-mail, or Facebook, or Twitter.

233.86.text:
And when it comes down to it, the bad guys
have a wealth of possibilities

238.35.text: when they want to communicate secretly.

241.34.text: One thing a lot of people do,

244.20.text:
they communicate inside
their fantasy worlds:

246.38.text:
places like 'World of warcraft'
and 'Second life'

250.15.text: which in a sense makes them deep web.

254.02.text:
to have a private conversation
with someone like in 'Second life.'

257.56.text:
All you have to do is slide up
to somebody on a park bench there

260.93.text: and have a nice, quiet conversation.

264.69.text: How does anybody know you are doing this?

272.78.text:
the Islamic State or ISIS may be lurking
down in 'My little pony' world.

281.26.text:
"Hi, Applejack,
what are you up to today?"

287.34.text:
I'm going to kill the President
with a big bomb

289.77.text: at four o'clock at the Convention Center."

295.43.text:
they can see inside these things,
inside these secret fantasy worlds,

299.43.text:
but are they really monitoring
the conversations of 7-year-old girls?

303.95.text: And even if they are, so what?

306.03.text:
You can talk in code,
you don't have to say 'President,'

308.90.text: you could say 'big cheese' or whatever.

310.78.text: How would they know? Because they don't.

313.23.text:
So I say that by monitoring us all,
they are wasting their time.

316.98.text:
And what are we actually achieving
by doing all this?

319.91.text:
We are destroying the freedom
that the Internet originally promised.

331.68.text:
If we are not careful, we are heading
towards a two-tiered Internet,

336.82.text:
a nice, superfast Internet
for those who can pay,

339.83.text:
and a kind of rubbishy one
for those who can't,

343.27.text:
and it is called
"the end of net neutrality."

346.69.text:
Once upon a time, there were hundreds
of small oil companies drilling for oil,

352.22.text:
and then, in time,
they all got taken over by the big boys.

356.17.text:
And now, the oil business is in the hands
of a few ultrapowerful corporations.

362.83.text:
And if we are not careful,
this is the way the Internet's going.

370.77.text:
we are going to be looking
at an expensive toll road,

373.46.text:
we are going to be looking
at the pay-TV model.

376.70.text:
And even if you think
something's free, it invariably isn't.

379.81.text: And it's true when they say:

381.26.text:
"If you are not paying,
you are the product."

383.45.text:
A quick example would be
you got a Gmail account

385.82.text:
a nice, free e-mail account
- thank you very much -

388.23.text:
but the thing is they are combing
for everything you send and receive,

392.18.text:
looking for keywords
so they can bombard you with advertising.

398.08.text: Sometimes, this is very helpful, I guess.

401.03.text:
You may e-mail a friend
and say: "I'll meet you in Venice,"

404.51.text:
and the next thing you know,
you've been bombarded with ads

407.39.text:
for cheap flights to Venice,
and hotels, and all the rest of it.

410.74.text: Or maybe, just once, just once, mind you,

413.80.text: you look up the symptoms of hemorrhoids

416.37.text:
and then, for the rest of life,
they never let you forget it.

426.11.text:
do we really want
these ultrapowerful corporations

430.12.text:
know every tiny, little thing about us
and store it all in databases,

435.73.text: so they can better harvest this for cash?

438.21.text:
Because that's the way
the Internet's going.

442.04.text: Threat number three: criminals and sickos.

448.04.text:
because so many criminals
have migrated to digital

451.62.text:
where they can carry out their crimes
in the comfort of their own living rooms.

455.51.text:
Con artists, confidence tricksters,
they are online too,

459.43.text:
they talk about heart strings
on dating sites,

464.20.text:
and they are even capable
of pretending to be us in a crisis

469.62.text:
and getting our friends to send 
money thinking we are in trouble.

473.90.text:
This happened to a friend
of mine last week.

477.55.text:
This is really scary, and it has happened
to everybody one way or another

481.85.text: people are getting these sorts of e-mails.

487.50.text:
that the other major threat
are the stalkers and the trolls.

492.77.text:
Today, stalkers
don't have to hide in the bushes.

497.07.text: Now, they can sip a latte at Caffè Nero

499.87.text:
and monitor multiple victims
in real time on the free WiFi.

506.48.text:
This is the rather aptly named
"Cree. py" surveillance tool.

510.72.text: You can download it for free.

512.42.text:
And it allows you to keep closed tabs
on any active Twitter and Facebook user.

519.01.text:
This is my daughter Rebecca's 
recent trip to Rome.

522.41.text:
I can see everywhere she has been,
pretty much what she has been up to.

525.94.text: Mostly, she has taken photographs of food.

530.03.text: You can move it up a notch

531.58.text:
because most stalkers today
have a wealth of possibilities,

537.47.text: you can get a phone tracking package

541.76.text:
allowing the stalker to follow
their victim's GPS signal,

545.39.text: to listen to all their conversations,

548.10.text:
and even to turn on
a camera or a microphone.

552.47.text:
You really don't want to make
any enemies in the digital world,

556.46.text:
not when reputation 
destruction is all too easy

559.57.text: and suicides are all too common.

564.26.text:
You can find him down
on the Tor hidden network.

568.41.text:
For 50 euros, he would just screw
with somebody for you.

572.64.text: For 200 euros, he'd get the passwords.

576.42.text: For 400 euros, he can bankrupt somebody.

580.08.text: Destroying a life cost a little bit more.

583.29.text:
For 500 euros, Rent-A-Hacker
will stuff a target's computer

588.43.text:
full of images of child sexual abuse
and then tip off to the police.

593.34.text:
So, believe me when I say:
the Internet's a very dangerous place.

597.67.text: But we can move from the deep web.

599.93.text:
We can all learn to be anonymous
when we choose to be.

603.92.text:
If they don't know 
who we are or where we are,

607.13.text:
they can't spy on us,
they can't bombard us with ads,

611.28.text: and they can't stalk us and do us harm.

614.16.text: So, what we could do, as a beginning,

616.16.text:
is to wean ourselves off
products like Gmail.

618.85.text:
I would talk more about 
the things that are available;

623.73.text:
This is a free e-mail service
from Iceland.

626.35.text:
It's really cool, very secure,
no one is going to comb for it

629.56.text: for ads or the rest of it.

631.14.text: If you don't like to be -

633.28.text: If you don't like being followed online,

635.19.text:
by whoever, the state, criminals,
corporations, all the rest of it,

639.50.text:
you can just put a free add-on
to your browser, it's a doddle.

643.73.text: Better yet, you see, Tor Firefox browser.

647.81.text: You can download this for free,

649.94.text:
it allows you to travel
directly Internet, incognito,

653.55.text: and to visit the dark side too.

656.09.text:
All you need to do is to type
'Tor Firefox' into a search engine,

660.30.text:
follow your on-screen instructions,
and hit press there.

663.53.text: You can seriously be anonymous online.

667.93.text:
Back in the '70s, people worried
that TV was bad for you.

672.81.text:
They said, 
"TV is rotting people's brains."

676.65.text:
Some people got so upset they made
this film 'Network,' starring Peter Finch

682.54.text:
as a crusty, old news anchor
who sees the light.

688.53.text:
it just wants people
to wake up and get mad.

691.80.text:
Sadly, I'm not allowed to play a clip
from the film for copyright reasons

697.58.text:
So, I want you to imagine Peter Finch
really, really angry shouting:

702.13.text:
"I'm as mad as hell,
and I'm not going to take this anymore."

708.36.text:
"I'm as mad as hell,
and I'm not going to take this anymore."

712.39.text: We should all be doing this.

716.87.text:
"I'm as mad as hell at all the spying,
at the commercial takeover,

722.87.text:
and all the criminals
and sickos around to get us."

726.51.text:
In the film, they're just worried
that TV is rotting people's brains;

733.94.text:
We are looking at the end
of the Internet as we know it

738.69.text:
because the Internet is being taken over
by all the wrong people.

744.40.text:
But we can do something about it,
we can all go deep web.

748.45.text:
It is not a place, it is a state
of mind, a way of being.

755.42.text:
we can prevent people monitoring us,
following us, doing us harm.

760.10.text:
I say, it's time we woke up
to the threats towards the Internet,

763.41.text:
it's time we stood up
and do something about it,

765.74.text:
it's time we stood up
and took back the Internet,

769.24.text:
"I'm as mad as hell,
and I'm not going to take this anymore."
